message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms suggest a galactosemia, which means the baby cannot properly metabolize galactose. Among the options, Galactose-1-phosphate uridyl transferase is the enzyme that is deficient in classic galactosemia, leading to the accumulation of galactose-1-phosphate and other metabolites.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms and the restriction of milk and other galactose/lactose-containing foods suggest galactosemia. Among the options, only Galactose-1-phosphate uridyl transferase is the deficient enzyme in galactosemia. Galactokinase deficiency will result in cataracts but not hepatomegaly. Aldose reductase deficiency causes congenital cataracts but no hepatomegaly or irritability/vomiting. Glucose-6-phosphate dehydrogenase deficiency causes hemolytic anemia but no hepatomegaly or cataracts.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms described suggest galactosemia, a genetic disorder that affects the body’s ability to metabolize galactose. The most likely deficient enzyme is Galactose-1-phosphate uridyl transferase (GALT), which is responsible for breaking down galactose-1-phosphate into glucose-1-phosphate.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms suggest Galactosemia, which is a deficiency in the enzyme Galactose-1-phosphate uridyl transferase. This enzyme is involved in the breakdown of galactose, and a deficiency can result in toxic accumulation of galactose and its metabolites in the body. Eliminating milk and foods high in galactose and/or lactose from the diet can help manage the condition. Galactokinase is involved in the conversion of galactose to glucose, but a deficiency in this enzyme causes another condition called Galactokinase deficiency. Aldose reductase and Glucose-6-phosphate dehydrogenase are not related to galactose metabolism.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms and the recommendation to eliminate milk and foods high in galactose and/or lactose suggest a diagnosis of galactosemia. Galactose-1-phosphate uridyl transferase is the enzyme that is deficient in galactosemia. Galactokinase deficiency can cause a different condition called galactosemia type II. Aldose reductase deficiency is associated with diabetic complications, and glucose-6-phosphate dehydrogenase deficiency is associated with hemolytic anemia.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms of vomiting and jaundice, along with hepatomegaly and cataracts, suggest galactosemia. Among the options, only Galactose-1-phosphate uridyl transferase is associated with galactosemia. Galactokinase deficiency and aldose reductase deficiency have different symptoms, and glucose-6-phosphate dehydrogenase deficiency is not related to galactose metabolism.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms suggest a hereditary metabolic disorder that affects galactose metabolism. Galactose-1-phosphate uridyl transferase deficiency is the most common cause of galactosemia, which can cause liver damage, cataracts, and poor weight gain in newborns. Elimination of foods high in galactose and/or lactose is necessary.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms described suggest a diagnosis of galactosemia, a hereditary enzyme deficiency that prevents the breakdown of galactose. The most likely deficient enzyme in galactosemia is galactose-1-phosphate uridyl transferase, which is responsible for the conversion of galactose-1-phosphate to glucose-1-phosphate. Eliminating milk and foods high in galactose and/or lactose from the diet is the standard treatment for galactosemia. Galactokinase deficiency would present with cataracts but not hepatomegaly, while Aldose reductase and Glucose-6-phosphate dehydrogenase deficiencies result in other conditions that do not match the symptoms described.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms and the recommendation to eliminate milk and galactose from the diet suggest a diagnosis of galactosemia, which is caused by a deficiency in Galactose-1-phosphate uridyl transferase. Galactokinase deficiency can cause galactosemia as well, but it typically presents with cataracts only in older children or adults. Aldose reductase deficiency causes polyol accumulation, leading to cataracts and other symptoms. Glucose-6-phosphate dehydrogenase deficiency causes hemolytic anemia, which is not consistent with the patient’s symptoms.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms suggest galactosemia, which is caused by a deficiency in galactose-1-phosphate uridyltransferase. This deficiency leads to the accumulation of galactose and its metabolites leading to the symptoms described. Eliminating milk and foods high in galactose and/or lactose will help manage the symptoms. Galactokinase deficiency and aldose reductase deficiency both cause different metabolic disorders, while glucose-6-phosphate dehydrogenase deficiency causes hemolytic anemia.
